transcripts.text: Eric joined league at Boulevard Lanes, AMF Boulevard Lanes, when, what, you were in fourth grade?  Third or fourth grade.  The first time I took Eric bowling as a little kid, he bowled over 120, and I was like, man.  And then he wanted to come back, and then he pretty much bowled every day for the past four years.
And he has 10... Perfect games, 300 games, and a lot of trophies.  One national title for team masters last summer in Florida.

I really like the competition, getting to travel around the states and bowl with some people, really cool people.  That's probably the best part is like, you know, meeting people, competing against them.  Well, now it's shut down, so we kind of just decided that we're gonna, you know, try and make a ball and win.

You get a pack of 10 used pins for $20.  Now he showed me this lane part on YouTube.  So we built the lane real similar to how a pro did it.  Wesley Lowe is a pro on the PBA Tour.  After setting pins so much, I got tired of that, and I was thinking, you know that little bowling alley at Incredible Pizza, they use strings.  So we used the strings, and one thing led to another.  We made another layer that kind of sets the pins.  And then after doing that, we were thinking, man, if we can figure out a ball return, and we were on the... at the aisle of Home Depot getting essential items and saw this plumber's PVC pipe, and my father-in-law was a plumber, and I kind of laughed.  I was like, I bet that would work for a ball return, so.  We just kind of every day started trying things and we learned about pulleys.  So it's like having school at home.  Eric's been learning how to use power tools, hammer, nail, screw gun, skill saw, jigsaw, all the things of a kind of like a carpenter.

Instead of using oil, we kind of switched it up and used polyurethane to coat the surface of the land.  It doesn't make the ball skid as far, but you know, it works.  It gives a pretty decent reaction.  So that's kind of what we do.

Really, anything that's father-son bonding with your kid, where you can do a project, it's great.  He was getting depressed that he wouldn't get in a hole, and I was getting depressed because I love watching him stride.  We made it happen.  Get out of the house.  Stay quarantined, but go to your backyard and do something.  Bowling Alley is kind of our family.  Mike Anderson, all those people that work there right now are out of work and it's closed.  But I play my saxophone there on Wednesday nights and Eric bowls every single day.  So we've kind of become Bowling Alley is our home.  So we're quarantined away from that home.  So we had to make Bowling Alley here our home.  Bring it to our home.
